meanings.def: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
examples: + speech ‘Hello!’ she said.
‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.
A legendary football coach once said, ‘Winning is everything.’
say something Be quiet, I have something to say.
Come and say hello.
Please say yes!
I didn't believe a word she said.
That's a terrible thing to say.
say something to somebody She said nothing to me about it.
say to somebody/yourself + speech I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’
say (that)… He said (that) his name was Sam.
Can I just say I'm not happy about this.
I have to say I was pleasantly surprised.
it is said that… It is said that she lived to be over 100.
say what, how, etc… She finds it hard to say what she feels.
‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’
‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’
‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’
say to do something He said to meet him here.
be said to be/have something He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.
Sorry to interrupt, but I have to disagree with that.
Could I just say something here?
If I could, let me stop you there for a moment and go back to your previous point.
Actually, we seem to have strayed a bit from the topic. Can we go back to the first point?
Just a moment, Sue. Can we hear what Jack has to say on this?
May I interrupt you there? I don't think that's true.
I’m sorry, but we’re running short on time. Can you please summarize very quickly so we can finish up?
I appreciate your enthusiasm on this topic, but I’m afraid we have a couple more people to hear from.
Could you two please discuss that issue privately after the meeting? We have several more items to cover and need to move on at this point.
I’m sorry, I really have to stop you there. We've run out of time.
Let’s save that conversation for another time.
‘Sit down,’ she said.
Anne said, ‘I’m tired.’
Anne said (that) she was tired.
What did he say to you?
I want to say something/​a few words/​a little about my family.
She didn’t say what she intended to do.
Have you told him the news yet?
Anne told me (that) she was tired.
Can you tell me when the movie starts?
Can you give me some information about the school?
The doctor told me to stay in bed.
The doctor told me (that) I had to stay in bed.
The doctor said (that) I had to stay in bed.
The doctor said me to stay in bed.
‘I am home, ’ he said simply.
‘I don't know,’ she said crossly.
‘There's nothing wrong with him, ’ she said airily.
‘Well, at least we tried!’ he said with a shrug.
‘You'll see!’ Lianne said with a smile.
A government spokesman was quoted as saying that they would take steps to restore order.
Can you honestly say you're sorry?
I dared not say a word about it to anyone.
I heard him say they were leaving tomorrow.
I've forgotten what I was going to say.

meanings.def: to repeat words, phrases, etc.
examples: to say a prayer
Try to say that line with more conviction.

meanings.def: to give particular information or instructions
examples: + speech The notice said ‘Keep Out’.
say something The clock said three o'clock.
say (that)… The instructions say (that) we should leave it to set for four hours.
say where, why, etc… The book doesn't say where he was born.
say to do something The guidebook says to turn left.

meanings.def: to express an opinion on something
examples: say something Say what you like (= although you disagree) about her, she's a fine singer.
I'll say this for them, they're a very efficient company.
Anna thinks I'm lazy—what do you say (= what is your opinion)?
say (that)… I can't say I blame her for resigning (= I think she was right).
I have to say I enjoyed every minute.
I say (= suggest) we go without them.
I wouldn't say they were rich (= in my opinion they are not rich).
That's not to say it's a bad movie (= it is good but it is not without faults).
say what, how, etc… It's hard to say what caused the accident.
It's difficult to say whether the story is true.
‘When will it be finished?’ ‘I couldn't say (= I don't know).’
Is it worth it? I would say not.
Do you have anything to say about this?
I wouldn't like to say what the impact might be on my business.
She wasn't at her best, it has to be said.
It's difficult to say exactly where it will land.
I hate to say it, but I think Stephen may be right.
I have to say I didn't expect it to be so good.
It is fair to say a considerable amount of effort went into the project.

meanings.def: to make thoughts, feelings, etc. clear to somebody by using words, looks, movements, etc.
examples: say something His angry glance said it all.
Just what is the artist trying to say in her work?
say something about somebody/something The museum's architects have managed to say something about our national story.

meanings.def: to show, sometimes indirectly, what somebody/something is like
examples: say something That says it all really, doesn't it? (= it shows clearly what is true)
say something about somebody/something The incident says an awful lot about his character.
say something to somebody This says to me that there is more here than you are letting on.

meanings.def: to suggest or give something as an example or a possibility
examples: say something/somebody You could learn the basics in, let's say, three months.
Let’s take any writer, say (= for example) Dickens…
say (that)… Say you lose your job: what would you do then?
Just say he refuses to talk to you.

meanings.def: to be much more difficult to do than to talk about
examples: ‘Why don't you get yourself a job?’ ‘That's easier said than done.’

meanings.def: very quickly; in a very short time
used to say that you understand a situation and there is no need to say any more
examples: ‘He's a politician, remember.’ ‘Enough said.’

meanings.def: to be very obvious or easy to predict
examples: Of course I'll help you. That goes without saying.

meanings.def: to be ready, unwilling, etc. to talk or give your views on something
examples: She doesn't have much to say for herself (= doesn't take part in conversation).
He had plenty to say for himself (= he had a lot of opinions and was willing to talk).
Late again—what have you got to say for yourself (= what is your excuse)?

meanings.def: to be angry
examples: He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it.

meanings.def: used to introduce an opinion that makes what you have just said seem less strong
examples: I sometimes get worried in this job. Having said that, I enjoy doing it, it's a challenge.

meanings.def: used when you are saying that something is likely
examples: I dare say you know about it already.

meanings.def: used when you are going to criticize somebody or say something that might upset them
examples: That colour doesn't really suit you, if you don't mind my saying so.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody that you have listened to their opinion, especially when you are going to express a different opinion
examples: I hear what you're saying, but you're wrong.

meanings.def: used for emphasis to say ‘yes’
examples: ‘Does she see him often?’ ‘I'll say! Nearly every day.’

meanings.def: used when you are commenting on a situation and saying that you are happy about it
examples: Most teachers, I'm glad to say, take their jobs very seriously.

meanings.def: used for saying that something is disappointing
examples: He didn't accept the job, I'm sorry to say.

meanings.def: used to emphasize an opinion
examples: Well, I must say, that's the funniest thing I've heard all week.

meanings.def: used to express surprise, shock, etc.
examples: I say! What a huge cake!

meanings.def: used to attract somebody’s attention or introduce a new subject of conversation
examples: I say, can you lend me five pounds?

meanings.def: it shows a good/bad quality that somebody/something has
examples: It says a lot for her that she never lost her temper.
It didn't say much for their efficiency that the order arrived a week late.

meanings.def: used to say that you would like something or to accept something that is offered
examples: I wouldn't say no to a pizza.
‘Tea, Brian?’ ‘I wouldn't say no.’

meanings.def: a bad situation will pass or be forgotten most quickly if nothing more is said about it
the best thing to do is say as little as possible about something
used when commenting on a situation to suggest that you could say something more or worse but prefer not to
examples: Let's just say he wasn't very happy about the decision (= he was very unhappy or angry about it).

meanings.def: used when making a suggestion or giving an example
examples: I can let you have it for, well let's say £100.

meanings.def: used to emphasize what you are saying or to ask somebody if they really mean what they say
examples: I mean to say, you should have known how he would react!
Do you mean to say you've lost it?

meanings.def: used to emphasize that the information you are giving is obvious
examples: The problem, needless to say, is the cost involved.

meanings.def: do not stop hoping
used to say that something was, or will be, done immediately
to never say anything good about somebody/something
examples: Nobody had a good word to say about him.

meanings.def: to be very shy or gentle
examples: He's so nervous he wouldn't say boo to a goose.

meanings.def: used to introduce a stronger way of describing something
examples: a difficult, not to say impossible, task

meanings.def: used to ask somebody to smile before you take their photograph
to say something important
examples: You said a mouthful there, buddy.

meanings.def: to refuse an offer, a suggestion, etc.
examples: If you don't invest in this, you're saying no to a potential fortune.

meanings.def: used to say that you understand exactly what somebody means or is trying to say, so it is unnecessary to say anything more
examples: ‘They went to Paris together.’ ‘Say no more!’

meanings.def: to say exactly what you feel or think
used to express surprise at what somebody has just said
examples: ‘He's getting married.’ ‘Say what?’

meanings.def: used to ask somebody to tell you when you should stop pouring a drink or serving food for them because they have enough
to give an order; to make a request
examples: Just say the word, and I'll go.

meanings.def: used to suggest that although you could say more, what you do say will be enough to explain what you mean
examples: I won’t go into all the details. Suffice it to say that the whole event was a complete disaster.

meanings.def: in other words
examples: three days from now, that is to say on Friday

meanings.def: used to introduce an opinion that makes what you have just said seem less strong
used to say that something is not very unusual or special
examples: She's a better player than me, but that's not saying much (= because I am a very bad player).

meanings.def: used to say that it is impossible to predict what might happen
examples: There's no saying how he'll react.

meanings.def: there are/are not good reasons for doing something, believing something or agreeing with something
without making something seem better, worse, more serious, etc. than it really is
examples: I was surprised, to say the least.

meanings.def: used to introduce a further fact or thing in addition to those already mentioned
examples: It was too expensive, to say nothing of the time it wasted.

meanings.def: I agree completely
examples: ‘We must stand up for ourselves.’ ‘Well said, John.’

meanings.def: would you like something/to do something?
examples: What would you say to eating out tonight?
Let's go away for a weekend. What do you say?

meanings.def: used to agree to somebody’s suggestion because you do not want to argue
a particular person must be obeyed
examples: Sarah wanted the kitchen painted green, and what she says, goes.

meanings.def: when everything is considered
examples: I know you're upset, but when all's said and done it isn't exactly a disaster.

meanings.def: used to say that nobody knows the answer to a question
examples: Who can say what will happen next year?

meanings.def: used to disagree with a statement or an opinion
examples: Who says I can't do it?

meanings.def: used to say that something might happen or might have happened in a particular way, because nobody really knows
examples: Who's to say we would not have succeeded if we'd had more time?

meanings.def: I agree with you completely
examples: ‘He's in a bad mood today.’ ‘You can say that again!’

meanings.def: used to say that you think the offer you are making is reasonable or generous
examples: Look, I'll give you £100 for it. You can't say fairer than that.

meanings.def: used to express surprise
examples: ‘They left without us.’ ‘You don't say!’ (= I'm not surprised)

meanings.def: used to agree with somebody when they say something about themselves that you would not have been rude enough to say yourself
examples: ‘I know I'm not the world's greatest cook.’ ‘You said it!’

meanings.def: used to agree with somebody’s suggestion

meanings.def: the right to influence something by giving your opinion before a decision is made
examples: say (in something) We had no say in the decision to sell the company.
People want a greater say in local government.
say on something The judge has the final say on the sentence.

meanings.def: to have the opportunity to express yourself fully about something
examples: She won't be happy until she's had her say.

idioms.def: to have the opportunity to express yourself fully about something
examples: She won't be happy until she's had her say.

meanings.def: used for showing surprise or pleasure
examples: Say, that's a nice haircut!

meanings.def: used for attracting somebody’s attention or for making a suggestion or comment
examples: Say, how about going to a movie tonight?
